TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated to the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) that I wanted to ask a number of questions about matters associated with garbage collection in the Australian Capital Territory. Has the Minister had an opportunity for a briefing in connection with the problems of Australian Capital Territory household garbage collection?
—I am informed that the officers here were not told that Senator Lewis had put in any questions at all. I am sorry about that. Someone's head will roll.

—I indicated to the Minister that rather than put a question on notice it might be a lot easier if I were to ask it at this level. I ask the Minister, for starters: What would be the unit cost of the collection of garbage from one household in the Australian Capital Territory? I gather from the shaking of the Minister's head that that information is not currently available. Is the Minister able to tell us what the award wages are for garbage collectors in the Australian Capital Territory? To assist him, I understand that garbage collectors in the Australian Capital Territory work shifts of about four hours per day for four days a week, making a 16-hour week, that for that their salary is approximately $370 and that they receive three months long service leave after 15 years. Is the Minister able to confirm that to me?

—I gather from the advisers here that the award is that a darg is set for so much work to be done. As the honourable senator knows, in the Australian Capital Territory and other places they run like mad and get finished early. The award covers the amount of work they do rather than the number of hours they work. I am not sure about the long service provisions. I know that there has been a dispute about that recently.

—I understand that, as you say, they run like mad and are able to get through their work much more quickly than perhaps would have been anticipated when the award was fixed. My understanding is that some of these people have other positions. Some of them may even have positions with the Public Service. I also understand that a large number work two shifts. In other words, they are able to get through two rounds of garbage collection and so, instead of receiving $370 per week, they are receiving twice that amount, $740 per week. Would those people be entitled to six months' long service leave at the end of fifteen years' service? In other words, was their claim in the recent dispute that not only should they be entitled to two salaries but also they should get two lots of long service leave?

(10.01)-I am informed that the working arrangements are between the contractor and the garbage collectors and the Government pays the contractor. I will find out the answer to Senator Lewis's question. It would seem to me that if someone had two jobs in theory he may be entitled to two amounts of long service leave. This is a matter which I think is quite fascinating and I will find out for Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will look at a couple of aspects that worry me about the Department of Territories. One of these is the current process-perhaps it is not even happening-for the review of ordinances. During the Estimates Committee hearing we were told that a law revision section in the Legislation and Legal Policy Branch was the area in which ordinances were being examined and prepared for change. Basically, this area in the Department of Territories is occupied by putting out raging bushfires. Apparently it does not have a comprehensive overhaul program for the large number of outdated ordinances which apply in the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I can give the Committee a few examples. I would like to get a feeling from the Department-this is a question to the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes)-on the time scales for revision. Can the Minister tell me when the trading hours, noise pollution, and tobacco ordinances, which are still matters of public controversy, are due to be reviewed? We have had promises and deadlines which have by now expired. There have also been considerable delays in essential amendments to the Air Pollution Ordinance and I would like to know when we expect to get any results on that.

We have the outstanding problem which led to the garbage strike, which has been mentioned by Senator Lewis, over the portability of long service leave. I am not certain that it is any more than a promise. When will it actually appear in legislation? Just before the garbage collectors dispute the taxi drivers had to threaten to discontinue taking government work to get fare increases which were promised three months earlier. Apparently, that happened as a result of industrial action. It seems that the Department is constantly on the brink of disaster. One of the Government promises we heard earlier was that people from the Attorney-General's Department were to transfer some drafting people to the Department of Territories. I would like to know how this program of transfer of drafting people is actually getting on. We are, in fact, told that we can expect another 25 ordinances and eight sets of regulations in the next six months but we do not know exactly what they will deal with and there are still these overhanging problems which are causing a considerable amount of disquiet in the community. It would be useful if the Government could carry out some type of efficiency scrutiny with the Department to try to determine exactly how this process is operating and also to try to develop some type of people and service oriented approach within the section of the Department which deals with social welfare. I would like to know from the Minister, who should have a fair idea of this type of problem, what plans are afoot to try to develop a more personal and service oriented approach in social service areas.

A number of problems have come out of questioning on the Estimates on this occasion and on the last occasion relating to legal matters. Problems still remain in relation to the early end of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority. One real problem is that we do not appear to have seen any final accounts, reports or statements from this Authority. When does the Minister expect to get any figures on what appears to be a fairly straightforward and simple operation? At least we were told so in the Belconnen Mall affair. It is a problem if we have all these ordinances hanging over us and a number of outstanding legal problems in relation to the Canberra Commercial Development Authority, particularly the redundancy payments. Apparently, the court has refused to buy into the argument whether the redundancy payments should be arranged under Public Service determination 509/77. Have those people been paid or handled properly? Is the Canberra Commercial Development Authority effectively laid to rest at this stage? We really need to know something about this matter. In the Estimates hearings I also raised the matter of the illegal towing away of the car of the anti-drug campaigner, Mr Skrijel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that not a matter for another place? This is the Committee of the Whole.
—I point out to the Minister that we have this large Department which has municipal activities. I believe it is something which needs to be brought out here.
—You do not have to turn this into a local government chamber. You will be talking about the dog catcher next.

—That is what the Minister has become-a Minister for dog catching and garbage collection. That is the real problem we have in the Department of Territories. Instead of self-government we have this type of situation.
—That is your fault. You are the butcher of self-government.

—That is not true but we will not call each other names. There are now no elected representatives, just an advisory committee. There is nobody to ask these questions but people like me in the Senate. That is a serious situation.
—Order! Senator Vigor, you are entitled to ask questions about the Estimates. You are not entitled to ask questions at large. They must be related to some item in the Estimates.

—I take your point, Mr Chairman. In fact, all the money in the Department of Territories is spent on this type of material. The types of questions that I was asking are central to the core and operation of the Department. Unfortunately, this is exactly the type of stuff that is normally done in State legislatures and local government areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I have one last question. I want to look at the decision that was made in the Budget, which has now been reversed, to tear up the contracts for fixed interest home loan repayments. Apparently, other people in the system had loan contracts in which there were rise and fall clauses. I would like to know whether the Department got around to charging those people the extra interest where there was a rise and fall clause in their contracts. I believe that after all the fuss this has been forgotten. If this is the case, it is a matter of revenue for this Department. I will not be very long on this, but I also understand that people who have tried to pay back more that the contract amount now have been asked to sign new contracts which have rise and fall clauses in them. If this is happening it is not very useful from a revenue raising point of view because it will certainly discourage people from paying off their original contracts. It seems to me we have serious problems. That is why I am pursuing these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry I lost my cool, Mr Chairman, but I firmly believe that the appropriations debate is a time to talk about the appropriations and it is a pity that the debate is abused in this way. I have had warning that Senator Kilgariff is going to do something like that too and that is a shame.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a large number of ordinances in the Australian Capital Territory. They are carefully monitored, I am told. I cannot give details of when those various ordinances are up for review. To some extent the Department of Territories is in the hands of the Attorney-General's Department, which has to fit in such reviews. For the Canberra Commercial Development Authority the accounts are with the auditors now. The Department of Territories, the Australian Government Solicitor and the Public Service Board are now determining the specific redundancy entitlements of former employees of the Authority and we will finalise these arrangements as quickly as possible. Financial statements setting out the details of the operation of the Belconnen Mall from 1 July 1985 to 27 February 1986 by the Authority and from 28 February to 26 March 1986 by the Department of Territories have been prepared and, as I said, are with the Audit Office. The statements will be presented to the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) as soon as possible. I did not catch the bit, when I lost my temper, about someone being towed away but I will refer that to the Minister.

I am told that with those contracts with rise and fall clauses in them the rises have been applied. I do not know about the details given by Senator Vigor concerning whether people who want to pay off their loans are asked to sign new contracts with rise and fall clauses in them. I just find it interesting that Senator Vigor can defend a situation in which people are paying interest rates of 4 per cent per annum when everyone else is paying 15 per cent per annum, but that is his business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the response to my questions regarding the tendering for contracts for the supply of goods to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands during the hearings of Estimates Committee F, I would like to clarify some matters in relation to the general tender process and the specific instance in which I am interested. On pages 384 and 385 of the Hansard record of 18 September the relevant discussion is set out, in which a Department of Territories officer advised that a ministerial decision was made that the shipping companies of Mr John Clunies-Ross, Sr, would not be permitted to tender for the supply of goods to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. As can be seen, the officer could not say why the ministerial decision to refuse Clunies-Ross contracts had been taken.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my understanding that, except in certain exceptional circumstances, contracts for the supply of goods or services to the Government must be called publicly. As I understand it, the contracts involving shipping supplies to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands do not fall into the classes of exclusions, which include things such as shipping military or classified equipment, or which apply when there is an urgent need to complete a contract which would not allow time for a public tender to be called. It is apparent that the decision to deny Clunies-Ross contracts was not taken on a commercial basis either, as the freight rates he was offering were extremely competitive. He could freight goods to the islands at a much lower rate than could other companies, because his line had a very good business freighting goods from Singapore to Perth but often had little cargo on the trip to Singapore, so it had plenty of space to carry goods which could be delivered to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

I understand that price, naturally enough, is a primary factor to be taken into account in assessing tenders for government contracts. On this basis Clunies-Ross contracts should certainly have been considered. I realise that there are other factors to be taken into account when tenders are received from prospective suppliers of goods or services, such as the record of the tenderer, reliability and such, but on all accounts the Clunies-Ross line appears to have been a perfectly reasonable candidate for the awarding of the tender. Yet here we have an admission by a departmental officer that the Minister for Territories at the time, Mr Uren, made a decision, which was followed through by his successor, Mr Scholes, that Clunies-Ross company tenders would not even be considered.

Having followed this matter through with other people, including Mr Clunies-Ross himself and his former shipping agents, I have come to the conclusion that Clunies-Ross was, to say the least, discriminated against by Ministers of the Australian Government in relation to the commercial transactions of his companies. Indeed, the Ministers and the Department involved were quite blatant-going so far, I understand, as marking tender documents to state that tenders from Clunies-Ross companies would not be accepted. Honourable senators may be aware that the Clunies-Ross companies subsequently went broke, and I think it is reasonable to assume that the fact that the companies were denied the right to tender for these government contracts would certainly not have helped the financial fortunes of the companies.

So the situation is that the companies of one Australian citizen were singled out for this treatment, apparently not on any commercial basis but at the whim of a Minister. I understand that, because it was a ministerial rather than an administrative decision, appeals which were made by Clunies-Ross to the Commonwealth Ombudsman were not able to be dealt with by that authority. One has to ask what could have motivated the Minister in taking this decision. The answer is fairly apparent. It was the Minister's determination, for whatever reason, to get Clunies-Ross off the islands. Indeed, I understand that that was the message communicated to Clunies-Ross, his shipping company and legal representatives when they attempted to find out why he had been blackbanned. So it seems that, in order to achieve a political objective, the Minister was prepared to use his muscle as a Minister of the Crown to drive an Australian citizen as far as bankruptcy.

I would like to know, and no doubt Mr Clunies-Ross would like to know as he was never informed of it, under what authority the Minister took the decision to refuse to accept tenders from Clunies-Ross companies. Just what are the rules governing the calling of tenders for services such as these? Do they have to be called publicly? Can the Minister specifically exclude particular members of the public from participating in the tender process? If so, under what authority? What right of redress does a wronged person have if the Minister does purport to exclude him? On what basis were the Clunies-Ross companies excluded from the tender process? How many other companies or individuals have been excluded in like fashion, and for what reason? Is it common practice to exclude companies owned by a particular person from tendering, without any reason being given other than that it was a ministerial decision?

It seems to me that Mr Clunies-Ross was the object of a victimisation campaign and the way in which he has been treated by a Minister in this Government is a disgrace. In the manual which deals with tendering procedures for government contracts it is clear that a tenderer whose offer has been rejected is entitled to be given the precise reason for the rejection. Surely a person who is not even allowed to get as far as putting in a tender is entitled to know why. I believe that the relevant Minister should answer all of the questions which I have raised today and clarify the specific instance of apparent victimisation of this Australian citizen. After all, in Australia everyone is supposed to be given a fair go but in this case there appears to be every reason to believe that there was victimisation and the little man in the street-that is what he is-was not given a fair go.

I add in closing that it is remarkable that the Clunies-Ross family is being singled out by the Federal Government to be exterminated, for that is what is happening, whether honourable senators like it or not, degree by degree. It is all the more remarkable because, after the first generation of the Clunies-Ross family, over the following generations it was probably three-quarters Malay and one-quarter Scottish. Since then the proportion of Cocos-Malay blood has varied. Now, Cocos-Malay blood still runs through their veins. In Australia, if a person has any Aboriginal blood, he can be recognised as an Aboriginal. The Clunies-Ross family, has not been recognised as being Malay. Despite its pioneering of an empty, remote Pacific island, its members have been treated as intruders. Yet they have had very many generations of association with the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Sometimes I think Australians can be ugly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff asked: What are the rules governing the calling of tenders for services such as these? The finance regulations and directions which derive from the Audit Act 1901 and the Commonwealth purchasing policy and procedures are the rules. Do they have to be called publicly? Yes, when the contract price is estimated to be in excess of $20,000. Can the Minister specifically exclude particular members of the public from participating in a tender process? Yes, by ministerial direction based on government policy; for example, the current government policy of not accepting South African tenders and also the policy against the Builders Labourers Federation. If so, under what authority? The authority is the published procedure relating to purchasing practice in the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual. What right of redress has a wronged person if the Minister does purport to exclude him? If a person is excluded by the Minister from participating in the tender process he can complain to the Ombudsman.

SPEECH.PARA: On what basis were the Clunies-Ross companies excluded from the tender process? The basis was that their tendering was not in the public interest, which is a ground provided by the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual. I think that is understood, in light of the history of the Clunies-Ross family on the island. How many other companies or individuals have been excluded in a like fashion and for what reason? I am not aware, but I will try to seek that information. Is it a common practice to exclude companies owned by particular persons from tendering without any reason being given other than that it was a ministerial decision? No, it is not common. In the case of Clunies-Ross, the shipping agent acting on his behalf was advised of the reasons in writing. I think that that covers all the questions asked by Senator Kilgariff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ask a number of short questions which touch in part on the matters raised by Senator Kilgariff. I ask first: Has the present Administrator, or past Administrators, of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands been either instructed or advised by the Department not to have any formal or informal communications with the Clunies-Ross family? I extend that question by asking: In the mind of the Department, is the Clunies-Ross family to be considered persona non grata? I ask further: Is there any intention in any way to seek to remove the Clunies-Ross family completely from Home Island, either overtly or covertly? As Clunies-Ross still has about ten acres of land on Home Island, if he commences a tourist industry on the island-it seems to me an absolutely idyllic location for a tourist venture-will he be commercially hindered, or in any way affected so as to be caused hardship in his endeavours to set up a tourist resort? Of course, the establishment of a tourist resort would require the landing of aircraft at the Government's airport. The final part of the question is: In the event that Clunies-Ross chose to develop some type of tourist structure on that part of the islands that belongs to him still, would the Department seek directly, indirectly, covertly, or overtly to make it so difficult as to make it not profitable, or would it discourage anybody else from in any way having any commercial transactions with him?

SPEECH.PARA: I now want to ask some questions that relate to the islands directly. One cannot help observing when one visits Cocos that there was a very prosperous and flourishing coconut industry there. The plantation is now quite overgrown. It is infected by beetles and has deteriorated very significantly; yet the Philippines and a number of other countries still commercially grow and harvest coconuts. Inasmuch as, to my knowledge, almost without exception, there is no revenue generated on the islands other than in the form of welfare payments of one type or another, or as a result of government expenditure, particularly by the Department of Housing and Construction, it seems to me that there ought to be a prospect of at least having that industry generating some revenue. As I said earlier, it seems an ideal spot for tourism. Has the Department examined the prospects in the same way as they have been clearly examined on Christmas Island by private individuals in res- pect of a casino and holiday resort? Has that matter been looked at on Cocos?

One is also very much struck by the fact that all the whites live on West Island and all the coloureds, the Cocos Malays, live on Home Island. There is a very clear dichotomy between where one race lives and where another race lives. Is there any intention to break down the physical barrier which has been artificially built by whites because they consciously and wilfully built all the homes and infrastructure for those homes on West Island? Is there any intention to move any of them on to Home Island so there is a better interaction between--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or vice versa.
—Or vice versa. Is it the intention to build homes and accommodation on West Island for the Cocos Malays?

SPEECH.PARA: There is one other matter that has been brought to my attention. When we visited the island we noticed a bulldozer which appeared, on the surface, to be of some commercial value pushed over the edge of a cliff. The area was becoming a rubbish tip. Clunies-Ross offered to purchase it according to what he told us, and he was denied the opportunity to so do. Is that normal commercial practice between Clunies-Ross and the Department?

TALK.START.PARA: —In listening carefully to the Minister's response to Senator Kilgariff, I got the strong feeling that we are in an episode of Yes, Minister. The Minister said that it was not in the public interest that the contracts were denied. He said that under all the circumstances that would be understandable. I am afraid that I do not understand the Minister at all on that point. I would like the Minister to develop that point. It seems to me to be a clear case of discrimination. It is not good enough to come in here and simply say that it was in the public interest. What criteria of public interest actually were involved in that decision?

—No, the Administrator of the Island has not been instructed to declare the Clunies-Ross family persona non grata, nor has she been instructed not to have formal or informal relations with the family. There is no intention to remove the family from Home Island overtly or covertly. Mr Clunies-Ross has not applied to the Department or consulted the Department about any tourist develop- ment on Home Island on his land. There is the possibility of a tourist development on Direc- tion Island, I am told.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, all the whites live on West Island where they are near the air facilities. All the islanders live on Home Island. I understand that that is their choice. I will get some details on that but I understand that there are no activities to change that position; it will be up to them. The main reasons that the copra plantations are in disrepair are their size, the poor land and the bottom has fallen out of the market, as Senator Crichton-Browne would know. It is not a viable proposition. A study is being made and plans are being developed for the pilot cultivation of selected fruits and vegetables using field crop and hydroponic methods. A horticulturist is to begin work in the Territory shortly and recruitment is under way for a development officer who will oversight all aspects of economic and localisation policy. I am told by the officers here that the bulldozer was rusted and not worth two bob, to use the vernacular. Therefore, it would not be worth--
—Why did they not sell it to Clunies-Ross when he offered something for it?

—I do not know, but I will seek details on that. I am no expert on bulldozers at the bottom of cliffs. On Senator Mason's question, I said that it was a matter of judgment by the Minister that it was not in the public interest. I am sorry I was a bit vague on it. I suggested that the criteria would have been the former relationship of Mr Clunies-Ross, and the difficulties in that relationship, with the Islanders but I will seek precise details from the Minister.
—At the risk of asking a hypothetical question, Minister--
—You will get a hypothetical answer.

—I would have thought that was likely to be the case. In the event that Mr Clunies-Ross were to approach the Department with a view to contemplating tourism, would he be received with sympathy or would the Department seek to ensure that he was in no way able to provide facilities on the Island?

—I am informed that the reaction of the Department would depend on the sort of project he wanted to set up. I dare say that if he wanted to set up a casino or a house of ill fame it might be a bit difficult but if it were something less than that it might be all right.
—It would be without prejudice?
—Yes, without prejudice.
—I would have to agree with a lot of the things that Senator Crichton-Browne has just said. I was recently on Cocos Island and I would have to say--
—It is a popular spot. You have all been there. I am the only one who has not.

—No, we were there with a Senate committee that was looking at things. It was enforced capture, I can assure the Minister. I would have to agree that the plantations are virtually out of control. What was obviously once a very good area is not becoming overgrown with trees from the coconuts that fall off the palms alongside the parent trees. They are springing up everywhere. In another few years the usefulness of the area will be completely ruined. The cemetery on Home Island that used to be well looked after is also a disgrace. In fact, everything on the Island, in my estimation, is a disgrace. In many areas--
—What about the schools?

—If Senator Zakharov wants to speak about it she may get up with some of her left wing rubbish about how she is leaving these people to sit around and collect all the money they get in all the ways that Senator Crichton-Browne said. I am suggesting that may- be they should be made to do some kind of work for the government handouts that they are getting. The place is a total disgrace. The feeling amongst the staff and the Administrator is also a disgrace. It is something at which the Department should well look. The feelings between many members of the staff there and the Administrator are anything but pleasant. No doubt a few of the people from Greenpeace and so on would say that the island is idyllic. It may have been idyllic once, but it certainly is not now. In many areas the rubbish that has been poured into the sea and left there to rust is a disgrace. Instead of having people sitting around on their tails doing nothing, letting all the plantations get overgrown, something could have been done. I ask the Minister: When will the Government take some action to get the place, including the cemetery which is mainly for the Chinese people, into some order of repair instead of leaving it as a haven for people whom I am sure John Laws would call social security layabouts?

—I think Senator Townley is being a bit unfair. The bottom has fallen out of the copra market. Because the Home Islanders cannot make any money out of it, they have lost interest in that. I am informed that they retain a fierce pride in their island and keep it tidy. The Government is compiling a report which was recommended--
—It is inaccurate information.

—Maybe the honourable senator's idea of tidiness is different; I do not know. Projects on the island are proceeding, as I understand it. Mr O'Hara from Cameron McNamara Pty Ltd has recommended that partial self-sufficiency is a reasonable objective and has suggested a semi-intensive poultry project, field production of selected vegetables, and wind driven generation of electricity to replace the use of diesel fuel. The Government has approved some of these. Shortly a horticulturist will be going there to look at the projects about which I talked earlier. I think the Government is acting. The simple fact is that, in the present market, people cannot economically produce copra there in that small quantity. I think everyone realises and accepts that. We have to have a replacement industry there, as we have everywhere else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have three very short questions closer to home which I want to ask, particularly relating to the activities of the Department of Territories in the education area. I refer to the proposed closure of the Watson High School which I visited on a recent open day. A lot of effort seems to have gone into keeping children out of the school. A lot of money seems to have gone in, as there was a major asbestos problem in the school. The school was told, after it had been operating for 21 years, that it will be closed down. It seems to be serving a reasonable area. Apparently there has been a temporary reprieve. Does the Government propose to close the school down? If so, what does it intend to do with the facilities, and what will be the cost of this exercise?

SPEECH.PARA: The next area about which I am particularly concerned and about which I will cut short my question is that of hydatid control within the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority. In this year's Budget there seems to have been a cut of $10,000 for the hydatid control program. It is really an important problem for the area and the surrounding districts because the Australian Capital Territory has the highest incidence of hydatids, and all of us are open to infection. About a dozen cases a year, involving people in the Australian Capital Territory or from the hospital catchment areas, require treatment for hydatidosis. In New Zealand and Tasmania, it has been shown that a long term education campaign can be very effective in reducing the incidence of infestation.

Feral animals in the Australian Capital Territory and surrounding areas are apparently, unfortunately, badly infested. This means that humans have to take sensible precautions in dealing with the animals. The contribution of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority has been to withdraw $10,000 from the campaign. To me, that seems insane in the current climate, as preventive activities would greatly reduce the cost of the Australian Capital Territory health system of this problem. I ask the Minister and the Department what they are planning to do about this very serious problem and whether they would enter into any type of advertising campaign to point out to people how they can avoid this particularly nasty but avoidable disease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Watson High School currently has an enrolment of 264 students. Its enrolment was projected to fall to 200 by 1988. The cost per student is considerably above the average for high schools. The school was given three years from 1984, with rich resources, to prove its viability. The ACT Schools Authority decided it should close no later than at the end of 1987 and not enrol students in year 7 in 1987. Meetings were held with leaders of the four north Canberra high schools concerning transition arrangements. The Watson High community will be offered a program for years 8 to 10 in 1987, with staffing for some 200 students at the same level per student in 1986. Schools with low numbers attract correspondingly low teacher numbers and, therefore, have difficulty in offering the range of curriculum options of larger schools. The Department of Territories' portfolio committee, with the Authority's representatives, will examine possible future uses of the building. I would have thought that in this day and age, in a Territory which imposes as much on education costs as it does, a high school of 200 or less is quite ludicrous.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the hydatid control program, approximately 12 cases of hydatid are treated in Australian Capital Territory hospitals annually. The vast majority of cases comes from outside the Australian Capital Territory. The Southern Tablelands region has the highest incidence of the disease in Australia since people such as Senator Archer and I, through an effective program State-wide in Tasmania, reduce the incidence of that disease in Tasmania considerably. The Australian Capital Territory Health Authority has given strong financial support to the hydatid control program since 1983. That support was given to establish the program and get the program going in the Australian Capital Territory. But the only way it will be controlled sensibly and effectively is through a strong national program. One cannot control hydatid by just having a hydatid control program in the Australian Capital Territory.

The Government agrees that, in order to maximise the effectiveness of the hydatid control program, local activities should be undertaken as part of a national program. The National Health and Medical Research Council's proposed national hydatid control program will be that national program. The Authority will incorporate its hydatid control program educational activities into its 1986-87 program. The reduction by $10,000 in an established program will not mean that that program is ineffective. The program will not be effective until the national hydatid control program extending throughout the Southern Tablelands area is introduced.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Local Government and Administrative Services
Proposed expenditure, $619,734,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wonder whether the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services can tell us--
—I thought you had to go home.

—I do. I just wonder whether the Department can tell us what has been done about selling the Anzac Rifle Range, what advertising there has been, what offers have been made and what stage it is at. I raise again the point I raised the other night as to whether there is any possibility of the sale of the range, if it must proceed, being deferred to allow the Bicentennial full bore rifle event in 1988 taking place. I can see no reason why the Commonwealth Government should persist with the sale so as to preclude that event taking place in 1988. The sale is in the hands of the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services. I know that it is not that Department's decision that the rifle range be sold, but I wonder whether there is any answer to the question that was raised under another item as to whether the sale could be deferred or handled in such a way as to enable the event to take place.

SPEECH.PARA: Those involved in planning the event have spent a considerable amount of money. A lot more planning needs to be done. It is not good enough for them to find out in about December 1987 or January 1988 that the event will or will not be able to go ahead. They need to know now so that they can cut their losses and cancel this prestigious event. Already about 400 people have registered to participate. The rifle clubs expect teams to come from about 16 countries. The tourist potential alone is significant. It is an important event for the Bicentenary. Why can the sale not be postponed to enable it to take place and so that the rifle clubs can be told now that the range will be available and that they can go ahead with their planning?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been approached by the rifle clubs that use the range and are concerned about the possible cancellation of the major international shooting event planned for the Bicentenary year. I have handed on the honourable senator's concerns about this matter, which she brought up the other night, to the responsible Minister and the Government and we are already considering them. The Department of Local Government and Administrative Services is consulting with marketing agents in developing disposal strategies and it is having discussions with the New South Wales State Planning Authority and the Australian Heritage Commission. We are only that far ahead at this stage. As I said the other night, the property is valued at something between $20m and $40m, which I think is a pretty expensive rifle range. Having said that the other night I have received a torrent of abuse through the mail-more than I have received on any other subject on which I have spoken in recent times. So, tonight I had better be very careful and not cause myself too much difficulty. I will get the answer for the honourable senator and for those rifle clubs as soon as the Government has considered their representations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Purchasing and Disposals Division of the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services responded to questions asked at the Senate Estimates Committees relating to its functions by saying that, in its disposals, it simply got rid of property from other departments. I asked whether there was any evident trend for the disposal of new items that may have emerged from purchasing activity in the May-June period of the year; whether items were over-brought towards the end of the year in order to use up departmental votes and, therefore, had to be disposed of. The Purchasing and Disposals Division said that it could see no indication of that in its disposals but it could not be certain of it.

SPEECH.PARA: This Committee provides the only opportunity we have to ask the Government why on earth so many over purchases appear to be taking place, resulting in the disposal, through the auction system, of brand new items. They are brand new items because a booklet produced by the Department states that lots marked with an asterisk have a sales tax rate applicable. To confirm that, the word `new' is placed in brackets after each such item. For example, `2 Pairs Gloves, 20 pairs Cricket Boots, 36 pairs Football Boots. (New)' were sold at auction for $140 on 17 June; `956 white shorts, 728 various white shorts, 7 Sports Caps, 5 Hockey Shirts, 12 Coats' were sold for $90. The list goes on and on. `Steam cooker Sterlec electric. (New)' was sold for $500 and `16 Fire Hydrants (New)' were sold for $375. `Various Pipes, Bends and Bonds (New)' were sold for $5. In addition `48 approximately Thimbles' were sold for $60 and `2 ACI Fibreglass Chopped Strand Mats (New)' were sold for $250. Why were these items bought in the first place? What is it all about? I do not want to hold up the Committee but it strikes me as extraordinary.

I have not found a French empire clock in these lists. The list contains the entry `22 Approx. Mud and Snow Vehicle Chains'. It also contains the entries `Wiles Field Kitchen Oven', which was sold for $325, and `50 Door Handles (Fridge) (New)', which were sold for $20. What is the Government doing running around buying 50 new door handles and then not using them? The next item is appropriate for some honourable senators opposite-`9 Track Roller Idlers'. We have some idlers in this place. These items sold for $650. The list also contains the entry: `2 Nashua, 2 Minolta 1114TC Photocopying Machines (New)' which got knocked down for $380. Obviously this is a great lark. One can go out to these auction sales and buy totally brand new equipment which the Government is flogging because it should never have bought it in the first place. I have one word of warning: One should not go out there if one is a senator or a member of parliament because apparently it is illegal for a member of parliament to bid. So one can get one's wife to do it. The list is just absolutely incredibly. I have read a few of the entries from one booklet. There are some more exciting things. I cannot understand why it would be necessary for the Department to sell `360 Approx. 100 volt Light Globes (New)' for $60. Cannot they be used somewhere to bring some light to someone in this Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —Find a socket to stick them in.

—The list contains `8 Retractable Supports', if Senator Puplick is interested. It also contains `6 Search Lights (New)', for $450. It includes a `Kendall and Gent screwing machine', if anyone is interested.
—How much?

—The price is available on application. The list also contains `5 Camera Cases (New)' and `Box of Surgical Instruments (New)'. Although honourable senators may have had enough, I will just give them a couple more. The list continues: `1 Porta Potti, 1 Portable Seat'. Another point I want to make is that, in addition to all of the new stuff which is being flogged because it should never have been brought in the first place, a mountain of used furniture is being sold in these disposals and much of that used furniture should never have been replaced in the first instance. I quote as an example the office of the Leader of the Opposition in Sydney. There was no request whatsoever for the furniture in that office to be changed earlier this year or late last year. The furniture was quite usable. In fact, the only request that I can recall coming out of that office was to improve the phone system which was not adequate. Instead of that, the phone system was not changed but all the desks were replaced.
—It should have been the other way around.

—If the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) had asked for it the other way around, he might have got what he wanted. But in every one of these sales there are pages and pages of desks, chairs and heaven knows what being sold for $10 or $20 each. The list goes on and on-boxes of new surgical equipment; you name it. I just wonder what on earth it is all about.

—I became aware of this strange system 20 years ago when I furnished a doctor's surgery by buying all the furniture at a Department of Supply sale, as it was in those days. Mind you, that was before I became a senator. All I know is that the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services is the department responsible for these disposals. The Department purchases things which are over the tender threshold of $20,000. Most of the items mentioned by Senator Michael Baume were not over that threshold. The Department arranges for the sale of excess goods from each department. I do not know anything about each of the individual items. However, I can assure honourable senators that this makes for good Hansard reading. As to the question of why it happens, all I can say at five to eleven tonight, having been here since 8 o'clock this morning, is that I'm buggered if I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two very short questions.

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators-Oh no!

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ask the questions, but I do not really see why a department, because it arrives at this time of night, should fail to be properly examined. We would have adjourned the debate and done this at some other time. I note that the Government has again gone for an accelerated rate of property disposals at this stage. It is claiming $105m this year. I would be very interested to know whether the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services is currently on track for this property disposal program, because last year only $18m of the budgeted amount of $48m was actually realised in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I want to raise is the problem of standards when buying electronic data processing and other equipment. I asked about this point during the Estimates committee hearings. A recent Auditor-General's report on the Pisces computer system in the Army made the point very strongly that there was a need for some type of control on project specifications very early in the process. Perhaps a small cell within DOLGAS could look at unusual contract specifications and maybe examine how similar purchases have happened in the United States, especially when we are buying equipment from that country. It could also look at the highly technical matters associated with computer software or hardware. I ask: Is there any plan currently to improve the use of the purchasing dollar in these highly technical areas by setting up such a specialist cell, which I believe would be very useful? We asked about this but did not get any answer about future developments at the time of the Estimates committee hearings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The revenue to date to Consolidated Revenue from the sale of properties is $4.6m and there is negotiated for settlement $13.5m, which is a total of $18.1m. That is out of an amount of $100m. I think that is not doing too badly-certainly better than last year. I did not hear all the honourable senator's questions, but I understand that he was asking about automatic data processing acquisitions.
—Do you want him to repeat it?

—No, I do not want him to repeat it. I understand that there is a major purchasing branch in the Department which is responsible for major ADP acquisitions. Is that all the honourable senator wanted to know-whether there is such a branch?
—No, it was not. It was basically whether there is any specialised knowledge on the computing and software area to try and help that.
—Yes, there is, and it monitors all the departmental strategic plans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I call Senator Jessop, and in so doing I inform honourable senators that this is the twentieth anniversary of Senator Jessop's admission to this Parliament and convey our best wishes to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. It is a pity that I should delay the House on this auspicious occasion, but I was attracted by a speech that was made on Tuesday of this week by Senator Sanders about the report of the parliamentary delegation to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the Polish People's Republic. In the course of his speech he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I think . . . the Soviets are preoccupied with peace because they lost 20 million people in World War II . . . We talk about peace, but we have never had our homes destroyed or members of our families killed.

I have been doing some research on people killed in wars and revolutions and by their own governments over the last century, and I thought I would take this opportunity to make some points about that. Senator Sanders repeated what has been described as the most extraordinary example of the Russian mythos, one that survives largely intact today. For that reason, I believe it proper for me to establish, for the parliamentary record, a more realistic measure of the casualties suffered by the Russian people in World War II. The figure of 20 million was first used by the Russian writer Suslov in 1965. Prior to that, in 1945, Mikoyan boasted that victory had been achieved with the least possible losses. From 1947 pro-Soviet writers in the West claimed that the Soviet Union had suffered 7 1/2 million war dead.

A careful analysis of the first post-war census was undertaken in 1959 and it revealed that something like 25 million more people had perished in the war years than had been expected. In addition, the projected birth rate was down by 20 million, possibly due to wartime decline and abnormal infant mortality. It seems that in all a staggering total of no less than 30 million Soviet citizens died in the war years. Under the Czar in World War I, in roughly the same duration as the German-Russian conflict in World War II and with approximately the same numbers involved, the Russians lost 1,666,000 dead. Of course the firepower in World War II was greater than in the first war, but in all other theatres of war casualties were considerably lower than those of the First World War. The British Empire, for example, lost one million men in the First World War and less than 250,000 in World War II. The Wehrmacht, which fought the same battles as the Soviet army, lost 1,419,000 killed and another 907,000 missing on the Russian front.

The number of Soviet soldiers killed is not known precisely because the Soviet Government did not keep records of soldiers. One Soviet demographer has estimated that 7,500,000 Soviet soldiers were killed, and if we accept that deaths totalled 30 million that leaves something like 22,500,000 civilian deaths still to be accounted for. The Germans captured 5,500,000 Soviet soldiers, three in five of whom where murdered or died of neglect; so, there were three million dead in what was a staggering nazi crime, although perhaps it could be said that the Kremlin contributed to and aggravated this crime because it refused to ratify the Geneva convention dealing with prisoners of war and because of the way in which the Russians treated German prisoners of war. If that three million is deducted from the 7,500,000 Soviet soldiers killed, the Soviet army lost in battle 4,500,000 men.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 990-day seige, 2.2 million died in Leningrad.

—That is a point too, Senator Kilgariff. Approximately two Russian soldiers were killed for every German. Such losses can be explained only by the barbarous manner in which the Soviet army waged war. For example, the Russians sent in penal battalions to test out minefields. Of course many of those Russian soldiers were killed in those circumstances. Others were sent in virtually unarmed, and were hurled in huge waves against German defensive positions. Svetlana Stalin, in her book Only One Year, published in 1969, described how the butcher Beria:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . carried out the abominable liquidation of whole army units, at times very large ones, who, during the swift German advance into the Ukraine and Byelorussia, had found themselves cut off from their own lines, and who later, against frightful odds, had found their way back.

Considering now the 22,500,000 civilians who died, it has been estimated that about 250,000 civilians were killed in German operations against Soviet partisans and 750,000 Jews were massacred by the Germans at Babi Yar and elsewhere. A further one million people undoubtedly died in 1941-42 in the Ukraine, when the Germans made no attempt to feed the urban population. Another million died in the seige of Leningrad and other cities, and 500,000 died working as slave labour in Germany and German-occupied territory. Thus four million civilian deaths could be laid at the door of the Germans. Further deaths occurred due to the scorched earth policies of both totalitarian combatants.

Allowing for certain other civilian casualties, there remains some 10 to 15 million Russian deaths still unexplained, and they may always remain that way. However, we know that casualties in the war against the Finns were high. We know that the Soviet Union forced large sections of its population to move from their homes to the East because they were suspected of being sympathetic to the German invaders, and this resulted in widespread epidemics and the death of many people. We know that the NKVD conducted purges, particularly in reoccupied territories, which culminated in regular war against Ukrainian nationalists and other opponents of the communist regime.

Millions from ethnic groups such as Crimean Tartars, those from the Caucasian republics and Germans from the Volga region were deported to Siberia. We also know that the death rates in the Gulag exceeded even the terrible rates achieved in peacetime. For example, Dimitri Panin, in his book The Notebooks of Salogdin, claimed that seven million Gulag inmates were slaughtered in the first year of the war. Finally, some five and a half million Russian prisoners of war and civilians deported to Germany were eventually recovered and over two million of them were forced back to the Soviet Union by Britain and the United States of America under the terms of the Yalta Agreement. Thousands of those were executed on re-entering the Soviet Union and the overwhelming majority of the remainder disappeared, dying in slave labour camps.

It is important that the Senate records these terrible deeds done by the Soviet Government against its people. Recently, Professor Kummel, of the University of Hawaii, in volume 4 of his work on conflict, established the following statistics for unnatural deaths in the twentieth century. Casualties in war and revolutions total 37 million. The number of people who have died at the hands of their own governments total 119 million, mostly under totalitarian regimes. Of those, 95 million suffered death at the hands of communist governments. This has happened not only in the Soviet Union, but also in Eastern Europe, China, Vietnam, Laos, Kampuchea, North Korea, Cuba and marxist states in Africa. In addition, we have before us the example of Afghanistan, a nation which has been subjected to Soviet barbarism since 1979. Over one million people have been killed and thousands tortured. Three million refugees from that war happen to be in Pakistan and another two million in Iran and Turkey.

Senator Sanders claimed that we Australians have never had our homes destroyed or our families killed. He is a new Australian and can perhaps be forgiven for not knowing about events in 1942 in Australian mandated islands, Darwin and other northern mainland towns. As Senator Kilgariff and all of us know, on the first bombing raid 243 people were killed in Darwin.

TALK.START.PARA: —And many Americans-on the base and in fighter planes.

—Many Americans were killed; that is true. That was only the first of 63 bombing raids on the northern part of Australia. We Australians who have been here for a number of years have suffered the travails of war and we seek peace with the same earnestness as do those who, because they preach appeasement, claim to have a unique responsibility for the preservation of that peace.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, many of our naturalised Australians-this is what also offended me in what Senator Sanders said-such as Lithuanians, Estonians, Latvians, Hungarians, Poles, Yugoslavs, Ukrainians, Russians and Czechoslovakians, not to mention our newer Australians from Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia, would take strong exception to Senator Sanders's claim that Australians have not had their homes destroyed or their families killed. Those people have suffered dreadfully at the hands of communist liberators preaching peace. They know that the Soviet Communist Party, which has kept the Russian people in subjugation since 1917, believes that peace will come about only when it has completed its domination of the world and imposed its style of empire upon all the peoples of the world.

The Russian people certainly suffered greatly in the Second World War at the hands of either one or other of the two totalitarian regimes involved. The army of the Soviet Union fought with great heroism, and without doubt carried the greater part of the bitter fighting against the Germans from July 1941. I am in no way critical of the Soviet soldier or of the Soviet citizens. Senator Sanders claimed in his speech that he was taught to hate Russian people. I doubt him. He is confused about the Soviet Government and the Russian people. The latter, the Russian people, are the victims of the former. I think that is a fact that has long been recognised by the West.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the first opportunity I have to defend my friend and colleague the honourable member for Mayo, Mr Alexander Downer, from a totally false, totally inaccurate, totally nonsensical attack in this place today by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who maintained his normal standards of decency and accuracy in that attack. In other words, the attack was totally incorrect. He alleged falsely that Mr Downer sought from the Government this year $14.4m to establish a national motor museum at Birdwood Mill in South Australia. In fact, what Mr Downer did was to write in support of a submission from the History Trust of South Australia to the Commonwealth Government. He wrote to support in principle that proposal. This is all reported, by the way, in the local newspaper. Senator Walsh has no excuse for misrepresenting what was said. I quote what Mr Downer said:

SPEECH.PARA: While the request for $14.4 million is ambitious in the current economic climate; the Federal Government should at least designate Birdwood as the National Motor Museum.
If it were to do that, then the museum would have a greater capacity to attract sponsorship from the business sector.

There is no suggestion of demanding $14.4m out of the Federal Government right now. On the contrary, Mr Downer simply wanted the museum to be designated so it could attract sponsorship from the business sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Minister has done is absolutely disgraceful.
—As the honourable senator says, it is disgraceful, but it is typical of that Minister's behaviour. Mr Downer went on:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst these plans have a great deal of merit--

I am quoting Mr Downer, and this is material which the Minister himself had available to him, but which he chose to distort when he chose to present a totally false picture of what Mr Downer was saying-

and the cost would probably be recouped over time, it should be recognised that the Government may not be able to afford to fund such a project at this time because of Australia's economic woes and the ever increasing Budget deficit.
This is absolutely contrary to what Mr Downer, according to Senator Walsh, is purported to have said. Mr Downer went on:
However, that should not inhibit the Government from making a decision to confirm the Birdwood Mill as the National Motor Museum with a commitment that it will provide what assistance it can.

We know that the Government is allocating money under the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment for this sort of project and we know that the Government's review of funding for museums will be completed in February 1987. All Mr Downer was asking for was a slice of that available money to the extent that the Government felt able to provide it. Specifically, he wanted the Birdwood Mill designated as the national museum. He was not after $14.4m, because, as he said, the Government obviously would not be able to afford it. My concern is that this Minister gets up in this place and continually blackguards people in other parliaments around Australia with no regard for the truth. I do not mind him blackguarding me; I am used to it. I regard it as an accolade when I am attacked by Senator Walsh. It does not bother me. But it certainly is a misuse of his status and standing in this place deliberately to set out on a course like that when he knows what the facts are, nonetheless proceeding, quite improperly, to denigrate a valued Opposition colleague of mine in another chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.19 p.m.
